children.subject: If you're an undergrad EECS student, you would need to petition to have a grad class count for UD units. You can get petitions from 203/205 Cory or from the ESS front desk.
I was asking for ls cs, but thanks a lot!
I guess it's probably still too early for staff to decide, but is this class likely be able to counted towards upper division units? Thanks a lot!
This might be possible given there are empty seats in the class, but it is up to the instructor. Please contact Prof. Ramchandran.
Yikes, this conflicts with another grad class I'd like to take, EE C220B. Do you know if it would be possible to audit at least the course materials (papers, slides, etc.)?
Is the class variable units (1-3 units) or 3 units? The eecs website says 3, but the schedule doesn't.

history.content:
Course Announcement: EE290S (Special topics in communications, signal processing and information theory)

Title:   Codes for the modern age: distributed storage, inference, computation, and learning

 

Instructor:    Kannan Ramchandran (kannanr@eecs.berkeley.edu)

 

Tuesdays & Thursdays: 11-12:30 (293 Cory Hall)

 

This course will cover codes for the "modern age," going well beyond their highly successful use in communication systems over the past few decades.  Topic areas covered will center around the use of codes for (i) large-scale distributed storage systems that form the core of today’s massive data centers; (ii) fast computation and inference that are designed to exploit sparsity in a variety of settings including for compressed sensing, massive sparse FFT computation, compressive phase-retrieval, quantum state tomography, and group-testing for a wide variety of applications such as imaging (MRI and optical), astronomy, wide-band spectrum sensing, scientific computing, and fast neighbor discovery for large-scale Internet-of-Things applications; and (iii) learning and computing for settings like graph sketching, decision trees, and reducing the latency of parallel machine learning.

 

The prerequisites for the course are basic probability (EE 126 or equivalent) and basic familiarity with signals and systems (though this is less important).   The class will emphasize breadth and should be accessible to motivated undergraduates who are interested in research, as well as incoming graduate students.  There will be no exams, but students will be expected to read papers and give presentations of selected literature.  There will be a final project that can feature either existing literature or new research, and can be theoretical, algorithmic, and/or experimental in focus.

**Please note undergraduates may enroll in graduate courses beginning next week during the adjustment period. Please first obtain permission from Prof. Ramchandran to enroll and then once the adjustment period has begun, forward the email to lraya@eecs.**
history.subject: Course Announcement: EE290S (Ramchandran)
